metadata.case_name: Rabia Bai v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Appellant Rabia Bai, citizen of India residing at Grange, Yercaud, Salem District, desired to acquire immovable property and learned in 1949 that premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras, was for sale.
Premises belonged to Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad who left for Pakistan in 1947 and settled there; executed power of attorney in favour of nephew Ahmed Abdul Gani.

Ahmed Abdul Gani came to Madras in April 1949; negotiations led to written agreement on April 29, 1949, between appellant's husband and Ahmed Abdul Gani to purchase property for Rs. 2,40,000/-; Rs. 1,50,000/- paid immediately in cash and bank drafts.
Sale deed engrossed and sent to Karachi for execution by vendor; received back, presented at Collector's Office, Madras, and stamped on June 27, 1949.

Income-tax clearance certificate obtained; sale deed registered on August 11, 1949; balance consideration of Rs. 30,000/- paid before registering officer to Mr. M. H. Ganni holding power of attorney from vendor.

Ordinance No. XII of 1949 promulgated June 13, 1949, extended to Madras on August 23, 1949; repealed by Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 on October 18, 1949; latter repealed by Act XXXI of 1950 on April 17, 1950.
Appellant applied for confirmation of sale transaction on December 19, 1949.
Assistant Custodian declared vendor's property evacuee property on January 11, 1951 under s.7(1) as vendor fell within s.2(d)(ii).
Assistant Custodian rejected confirmation on July 31, 1951 under s.40(4)(c) due to feverish hurry by vendor.

Custodian on appeal found valuable consideration but not good faith; relied on vendor leaving in June 1947 due to disturbances, permanent settlement in Pakistan, desire to convert properties to cash; letter from vendor to Mohideen on July 4, 1949 stating 'if the matter is delayed there would be many sort of new difficulties as you know that the Government are passing new rules every day'; rejected under s.40(4)(a) and (c) on February 4, 1953.
Custodian-General in revision agreed no good faith due to vendor's conduct, haste, anxiety in letter; intent to evade restrictions; dismissed on July 4, 1954 under s.40(4)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the sale transaction was entered into in good faith under s.40(4)(a) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, given vendor's haste and intent to evade impending evacuee laws in Madras.
Whether good faith should be construed per s.3(22) General Clauses Act, and whether absence of evacuee law in Madras at time of transaction affects good faith.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transaction supported by valuable consideration; appellant acted in good faith; good faith of vendor to be assessed when no evacuee law applied to Madras, so free to deal with property.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.40(4)(a) Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950

petitioner_arguments.text: Good faith per s.3(22) General Clauses Act: done honestly, even if negligent; intent to avoid future law not dishonest.
Government policy via press note May 13, 1949 to confirm transfers by Mohammedan evacuees to Indian nationals subject to income-tax certificate and dues.

respondent_arguments.text: Vendor acted without good faith: left India 1947, settled Pakistan, hasty sale to convert to cash and take to Pakistan; letter July 4, 1949 shows anxiety to complete before new rules.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.40(4)(a) Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950

court_reasoning.text: Good faith required of both vendor and vendee under s.40(4)(a); more stringent than T.P. Act s.53(1); appellant's good faith irrelevant if vendor lacked it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Good faith of vendor assessed separately.

court_reasoning.text: Good faith not strictly per General Clauses Act s.3(22); context of Act's object to preserve evacuee property for inter-government adjustment; retrospective provisions from Aug 14, 1947.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intent to defeat apprehended evacuee law not honest.

court_reasoning.text: No evacuee law in Madras at time irrelevant; vendor knew laws extending province-wise; letter shows evasion intent; upholds rejection under s.40(4)(a).
Press notes/circulars subject to statutory provisions; authorities decide under law.

holdings.text: Expression 'good faith' in s.40(4)(a) construed in context of Act's aim to prevent evasion of evacuee property protection; deliberate intent to defeat apprehended law lacks good faith.
Custodian properly rejected confirmation under s.40(4)(a).

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (XXXI of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs confirmation of transfers by evacuees; rejection if not in good faith or for valuable consideration, prohibited, or other reasons.

statutes_cited.name: Ordinance No. XII of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposed restrictions on evacuee transfers; extended to Madras Aug 23, 1949.

statutes_cited.name: Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed prior Ordinance; transfers after Aug 14, 1947 ineffective without confirmation.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Contrasted: protects bona fide transferee for consideration unlike s.40(4)(a).

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897 (X of 1897)
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of good faith (honestly, even if negligent) not applicable if repugnant to context.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; Custodian-General's order rejecting confirmation of sale under s.40(4)(a) upheld as transaction lacked good faith due to vendor's intent to evade evacuee laws.

key_quotes.text: 'if the matter is delayed there would be many sort of new difficulties as you know that the Government are passing new rules every day.'
key_quotes.speaker: vendor
key_quotes.significance: Vendor's letter showing haste to evade impending evacuee laws.

key_quotes.text: An intention to defeat the provisions of the Act cannot be said to be honest in the context.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of good faith under s.40(4)(a).

key_quotes.text: the expression good faith used in s. 40(4)(a) has been properly construed by the respondent when he held that a deliberate intention to defeat the apprehended application of the evacuee law which was responsible for the transfer in question brings the transfer within the mischief of s. 40(4)(a).
key_quotes.speaker: court
